Award.AwardTitle: Exploring the Physical Chemistry of the Catalysis-Based All-Vapor Instant Formation of Gas Hydrates at Moderate P and T (180-220 K)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Prof. Paul Devlin of Oklahoma State University is supported by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program of the Chemistry Division to study the basic physical and chemical properties of clathrate hydrates. Clathrate hydrate formation, typically from liquid water or ice, is so slow as to often discourage studies of the rates and mechanisms of the process. The most exciting and promising discovery from research supported under prior awards is a completely new method of hydrate formation that reduces the reaction time to the subsecond scale. A generally slow mixing process has been shunted by using an all-vapor methodology with component guest molecules fully mixed with water vapor. Pulsed into a cold chamber the vapor quickly condenses to aqueous solution droplets that instantly crystallize as 100% gas-hydrate particles of an aerosol. A catalyst is still required at the current stage of knowledge, but advances in the all-vapor method sought in this phase of the project may aid technological developments in a) the production of methane from abundant ocean-sediment deposits of methane hydrate, and b) the concentration/storage of gases such as methane and CO2 as hydrate guests at greatly reduced pressures. It has been shown, for example, that humid air including CO2 is a vapor mixture suited to the all-vapor formation of a gas hydrate provided a catalyst is included

A clathrate/gas hydrate is most simply described as a host ice-like lattice of water molecules with incorporated small cages that serve as molecule-sized traps holding small organic or inorganic guest molecules. Because of an exceptional abundance in nature and their significant environmental and technological implications, they have been an object of many investigations over the past century. Much is known about their occurrence and physical properties; less about their participation in H-bond chemistry and the mechanisms of their formation. In this project, Prof. Devlin and his undergraduate research assistants will pursue the development of methods of gas-hydrate formation and control that will facilitate gas -hydrate science applications for controlling gases such as carbon dioxide and methane in the energy industry and the environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Rapid Formation of Gas Hydrates at Moderate P and T (180-220 K):

  Gas hydrates are ice-like solids composed of ~ 85% water molecules. They embody small cages that are ideal in size for the entrapment of small molecules, such as methane and carbon dioxide. These cages, that form within the gas hydrates from extensive water-to-water bonding of moderate strength, can hold the other ~15% of small hydrate molecules as guests. These hydrates have long been recognized as important natural components of cold systems such as comets, ice-caps of our Earth, and the northern reaches of Canada and Russia. These unusual hydrate structures with the inherent ability to store gas molecules have long been the target of extensive scientific studies. Many interesting potential technical applications have been imagined but remain largely unrealized. Nevertheless the activity has accelerated in recent years for three practical reasons: 1) a large fraction of the best of the fossil fuels on Earth, namely methane, resides in hydrate cages on the continental shelves, 2) mankind is searching for ways to sequester carbon dioxide formed from burning methane. One possibility being tested is to release methane using carbon dioxide as a stable substitutional guest and 3) gas hydrates are important components throughout our galaxy so their science and technology is basic to considerations of our future in space. 

 

 There are fundamental reasons why gas-hydrate science and technology has not kept pace with the interest or need. The loading of hydrate cages has proven to be so difficult that formation methods have depended on extremely high gas pressures to force small molecules to move thru a barrier; i.e., the initial gas-hydrate crust. Even then the process is very slow with days required to fully load even mm-sized particles. Our involvement with gas hydrates, with focus on this problem, began in 1980. We quickly found that, unlike for most small molecules, the hydrate of the smallest ether (ethylene oxide) formed instantly when ether and water vapor were molecularly mixed during codeposition as a cold film (120 Kelvin). Over the next few years we used NSF supported research to instantly prepare numerous gas hydrates successfully, reaching the conclusion that rapid formation depended on some of the caged guests being able to bond with the water of the walls. This was based on an earlier NRC Canada study showing that the presence of ether molecules increased the system molecular mobility by orders of magnitude. Apparently this special mobility also accelerated hydrate formation rates by orders of magnitude with formation achieved in seconds rather than hours/days.

 

 In the days before extensive computational chemistry was possible this new situation was described in a series of conjectures we presented (J. Chem. Phys. 1987, 87, 4126), some of which have been realized (e.g., W. Kuhs, Nature, 2014, 516, 231… a new phase of ice).  More recently, using more powerful computers/computational methods, the important details of how 100 % gas-hydrate formation can occur in microseconds became clear. Clarity came from the efforts of our deceased computational collaborator from the Hebrew University (Victoria Buch…, PCCP, 2009, 11,10245) using powerful programs originated by Parrinello’s Swiss group with special insights from the MIT group of Bernard Trout. Experimentally, the microsecond timescale was achieved using an all-vapor method within a supersonic jet in the Ohio State U. laboratory of Barbara Wyslouzil. That study used conditions we described earlier for all-vapor gas-hydrate formation in a cold chamber (Chem. Phys. Letts. 2010, 492, 1-8).

 

 The view that has emerged from combination of the computational and experimental all-vapor gas-hydrate data is a modern one of the conditions required for catalyzed microsecond formation of gas hydrates that I refer to as the Trout-Buch model. The sampling requirements for such a time is now clear. There are two critical modifications that offer a control with promise for a genuine expansion in the technological value of gas-hydrates. They are 1) the value of certain guest molecules as molecular catalysts and 2) the molecular-level premixing of the components possible through all-vapor premixing of any guests and water vapor. Our most recent studies have been directed to optimizing the formation conditions that flow from points (1) and (2). This involves overcoming limitations some of which have been identified. The most recent NSF-funded research has continued our experimental all-vapor catalytic studies in parallel with computational results from the group of Nevin Uras-Aytemiz of Turkey. Most surprisingly the combined results show that the all-vapor method with subsecond gas-hydrate formation allows trapping of exceedingly reactive molecules such as hydrochloric acid. Perhaps more importantly, these combined studies have identified ammonia (NH3) as the strongest catalyst of gas-hydrate formation presently known. The latter should permit significant reduction in the necessary quantity of catalyst while HCl as a hydrate guest suggests a future with many new controlled chemical reactions.
